response.answer_text: Listening without framing a response. Listening without judgement. Listening to understand. Listening for the subtle clues to what is behind the words. Listening not to diagnose but to assist. In my work as a military chaplain, my opening line with most clients is: “What’s going on?” This leaves the space for the client to tell me whatever they want or don’t want. After that, my most frequent sentence is: “Tell me more about that.” What I am trying to do is to understand the situation as the client understands it. They may be clearly mistaken or they may be clearly delusional. That doesn’t matter to me because it is the lived reality of the client. From there, I can find out more about the situation from other points of view and then work to solve problems, including the problem of the client’s lived reality not being objective reality. But I would not even address obvious errors in the client’s reality while the client is speaking and I am listening. That turns listening into an argument, not an exploration of the client’s thoughts, emotions and plans. I can’t tell you how many clients resolve their issues by being heard. In many cases, being heard is all the client needed.

I should say one listen truly when one pay true attention to the source of the sound/speech, truly trying to comprehend the meaning, and truly trying to get the message fully. But as we forget very fast, particularly when the sound/speech is very long, we can try to get the main points as much as possible. When the sound/speech is short and precise, we should get it perfectly. There are many noises in most spaces. We don’t pay attention to them. But often a prevailing sound can emerge - such as alarm. When we hear it and know what it is, we react accordingly. There is understanding in hearing. When someone is speaking in life, in audio or video, we still try to grasp the meanings. When we understand the seriousness, we would stop doing what we do and stop and listen.

In my opinion, true listening is when you can put aside all prejudices, all opinions, and look at someone as a human. A mistake-making, happy, sad, human. It’s when you cross your legs, fold your hands in my lap, and say “Tell me.” If you want someone to tell you, and feel at ease while doing so, you need to make that clear. Hope this helps!
